(beat) More. Music to Frank's ears. Roy KEYS the IGNITION.  58 59 60 61 62 63 64 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 35.
Roy enters. As we hear him continue --
We'll pull the Jamaican switch on him. He knows you, so you're rope, I'm inside. Think he knows anything about international finance? -- he moves briskly through --
-- and --
-- then into --
-- where he approaches a CLERK.
May I help you?
I'd like to access my safe deposit box. J-215.
(offering a form) Signature and pass code, please.
The bank Clerk removes a large safety deposit box, sets it on a viewing table, then leaves Roy alone with it. Roy opens it, then withdraws from his jacket two envelopes -- one white, one manila.

Roy faces his professional costume closet: several suits, high to low end, plus a gallery of pristine shoes, a number of pairs of eyeglasses. Roy tries on a pair, checks himself in the mirror.  65 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 36.
Roy on the phone again.
Where? (checking his watch) Where else. One hour. He hangs up. A KNOCK at the door. Roy looks alarmed. He just got off the phone with Frank -- who else could that be?
Opening on Angela, backpack and skateboard at her feet.
Remember me? Roy nods, bemused.
You just in the neighborhood?
Took the bus. Think I could come in a sec? Panic flickers across Roy's face. No one but Frank has crossed this threshold in many years. He opens the door wider and she steps inside. She peers about.
Nice.
Huh?
It's nice. Your place. I bet you're wondering how I got your address. He wasn't.
Off your car insurance, in your glove compartment. Roy feels suddenly uncomfortable in his own home. (CONTINUED )
So what's going on?
Mom and I had sort of a fight. It happens once in a while. I usually take off for a day or two to let her calm down.
Take off?

Normally I go to Carrie's. Only her family's on vacation. And I thought, since we seemed to hit it off so good last time -- (hoping Roy will complete the thought; he doesn't) -- I could sleep on the couch?
(cardiac arrest) You wanna stay here?
I could pay you back by cleaning up or something -- (as she gazes around spotless room; then re: his glasses) You wear those to read? They make you look kinda old.
These're just for -- (remembering) I gotta go. I got a business meeting.
This late?
Antiques wait for no man. (half to himself, half to her) Is it okay if I leave you here?
Sure. I can watch TV. (CONTINUED )
65 66 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 38.
Roy searches around the room, as if a television will magically appear.
You don't have a TV? You seriously don't have a TV? He smiles, sheepishly.

There's a couch. If you want to sit. Or there if you prefer. Or the couch. She moves to the couch, amused by his nervousness; of course, she treads right across the carpet. Roy averts his eyes, starts for the door...
You want me to pick up anything on the way back? Ice cream?
New York Super Fudge Chunk.
What?
That's my favorite flavor. New York Super Fudge Chunk.
New York...?
Super Fudge Chunk.
Chocolate. Don't open the door for anybody.
Quietly as he can, Roy locks the front door. Hesitates for a moment. Can he do this -- leave a fourteen-year- old girl alone in his house? He must.  67 68 69 70 39.
Roy pulls his Caprice into a distant view of the club. Frank taps on the passenger side window and Roy unlocks the door.
(re: Roy's glasses) Hey, I like those. They make you look --
Old?
(hesitates, then) Older.
How long's he been inside?
Twenty minutes.
You got your lines down?
You got my money? Roy withdraws the standard white envelope from his jacket and flings it at Frank.

As glamorous an establishment as you might imagine. Roy enters, pays the cover charge at the door and spots -- by way of a mirror -- Chuck Frechette drinking alone at the bar. He finds himself a table.
While Roy's away, Angela snoops. Here she opens drawers: just clothes.
Here she opens cupboards: just cans of Chicken-of-the- Sea.  71 72 40.
Here she stands on a chair and pries atop bookshelves: nothing here, not even dust. But from this perch, the ceramic horse in the corner draws her attention.
As Roy sips a club soda:
Good evening. His eyes stray up to hers (who knows the last time he faced a bare midriff) --
Care for a dance? -- then flash to the door as Frank enters. Frank spots Roy and heads his way. Roy glances back at the bar: Frechette, eyes on the girls, didn't notice Frank enter.
Not just now. The Stripper departs, passing Frank.
Thanks, honey. Come back later for me, though, okay? Frank stands over Roy and extends his hand.
Arden. Hope I didn't keep you.
(rising to shake) Good to see you, Bob. (voice dropping) At the bar. He missed you come in. Frank nods, then whistles to a passing waitress, loudly:
Hey, can I get a Bud?! Everyone turns their heads at that, including Frechette, who recognizes Frank. (CONTINUED )
(back to Roy) That do the trick?
Let's sit. They do. Frechette starts off his barstool toward them. Roy monitors his approach.
We in business?
On my next drink. Another stripper passes, and Roy's distracted an instant.
I told you you'd like it here. Roy picks up his drink, cueing Frank to reach into his windbreaker, remove the white envelope, and drop it on the table --
Don't spend it all on one girl, huh? -- so that it lands just as Frechette arrives, tie tugged loose, whiskey in hand.
Hey, Bob...

(he turns) Hey, Chuck, I didn't know you were here. Frank stands to shake hands, but Frechette's eyes drop to the white envelope on the table: a slim stack of $100's peeks out from within. Roy notes Frechette's glance and quickly palms the envelope into his lap.
(awkwardly) Ah, Chuck Frechette, this is my friend, Arden -- Roy shoots Frank a look: no names. Frank shuts up. (CONTINUED )
Hiya. Roy nods hello, none-too-pleased, then resumes his stare at Frank: get him out of here.
(to Frechette, confidentially) Say, Chuck, we got a little business to settle up here. You mind if -- Frechette gets the idea fast: something not-quite-legal is going down here, and he's not welcome.
Sure, Bob. I'1l be over at the bar.
Great. Thanks.
(to Roy) Nice meeting you. Frechette retreats, curiosity piqued. Frank sits back down.
Fish in a barrel. Roy waits until Frechette has returned to his barstool and is clandestinely watching and then --
-- he removes the manila envelope from his coat and hands it to Frank/"Bob": a trade.
As Frank glances inside Roy's manila envelope (filled with British pounds), Roy glances at Frechette, whose attention jerks back to the girls.
He's piqued. You good to go? (CONTINUED )
72 73 74 75 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 43.
Does the Pope shit in the woods?
Just say yes, okay? (rising) So long, Bob.
See you in the morning, Arden. Roy leaves Frank, ignoring Frechette on his way out the door. As soon as he's gone, Frechette starts toward Frank.
Roy picks his way through various cartons of ice cream. Squints through his fogged glasses, then remembers he does not need them.
A carton of New York Super Fudge Chunk makes its way down the conveyor to join a few more cans of tuna. The Check- Out Woman adds a pack of Winstons to the bunch.
Big night planned?
Huh? Oh, it's not for me.
Right. You have kids overnight? Roy laughs at the absurdity of this. The Check-Out Woman doesn't understand, of course, but she laughs with him.
Roy enters, locks the door behind him.

Angela? She sleeps atop the couch, arms and legs splayed every which way. Roy approaches, sets down the ice cream, and!--!for the first time in his career as parent -- finds a blanket to drape over her. (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 44.
(groggily) Roy?
Go to sleep.
How was your meeting?
Good. I sold a nice piece. Angela smiles, half-asleep. He starts to go.
Why'd Mom leave you?
You'd have to ask her.
I did. She didn't want to talk about it. Called you names. That's why we got into a fight. Roy smiles. Touched she stuck up for him.
She said you were a bad guy. You don't seem like a bad guy.
That's what makes me good at it. He rises, heads to his room, and just before he turns off the living room light, Angela rolls over under her blanket, eyes closed, murmuring:
I don't think you're a bad guy. Roy smiles, shuts the light off. Immediately: KNOCK- KNOCK.
Frank is knocking. Roy opens the door, squints at the light, careful not to let Frank peer in. (CONTINUED )
76 77 78 79 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 45.
I wish you could have been there. Oh, I reeled him in --
Do we have to do this now?
I got your money.
Shh-shh-shh. Conscious of Angela asleep inside, Roy slides out the door and closes it behind him.
What's going on? (shocked) You don't have someone in there?
Roy and Frank huddle on the sidewalk, Roy out of doors and anxious. Frank returns the manila envelope to him.
The second you left the place, he was off his barstool. He's in. Oh, man, is he in. He wants to meet tonight. Roy glances back at his house. A window shade shifts slightly: is Angela spying?
Push it to tomorrow. Lunch. Let his greed meet his imagination.
Roy returns to find his couch empty and the shower water running in the bathroom. He seizes the opportunity to sneak both envelopes of cash into the ceramic horse.
Angela, her hair still wet, digs a spoon into the pint of New York Super Fudge Chunk. Roy, meanwhile, sneaks his morning medication down his throat. (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 46.
You sure I can't give you a ride home?
That's okay. Mom can pick me up. Roy reacts: the prospect of confronting Heather rattles him.
Who was that guy who came by earlier?
Who? Oh. A business associate.
What's his name?
Frank.
How come you didn't want him to see me?
I didn't not want him to see you. (re: ice cream) Shouldn't you... eat eggs or something?
All you've got here is tuna. Lots and lots of tuna. And one TV dinner. TV dinners are cool. You should get the TV to go with ‘em. Roy stiffens, pissed: someone went snooping.
Angela's on the phone:
Hi... No... No... Guess... (beat) What if I am? So? He's my father... (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
ANGELA (CONT'Dbeat) I don't care. I don't care. I will if I want. Across the room, Roy grows more distressed as Angela grows more petulant. Now she quiets down.
I know. I know. Okay, I promise. Yes, I promise! ‘Bye. She hangs up abruptly.
She mad?
At me. Not you. Roy looks relieved.
She said she was gonna call the police -- So much for relief.
-- but now she just wants me home in time for summer school.
When's that?
Monday.
Today's Thursday.
That's okay, isn't it?
Roy is doubled over on the couch, his arms sagging down across his legs, head buried between his knees. (CONTINUED )
And one more time, deeply... (as Roy breathes in) Hold it -- one, two, three, four!-- and out.
You've got stains.
I beg your pardon?
In your carpet.
You can sit up. (as Roy does) Is that what you were thinking about? Stains in my carpet?
And that I have a fourteen-year- old girl I barely know living in my house.
It's just for the weekend.
But I've got a -- there's a big piece coming on the market I'm brokering and -- it's just not a good time.

When is it ever a good time for anything? I realize this is sudden, Roy, and you may feel unprepared, but trust me, they’re not so difficult, kids. Most of all you have to focus on the basics: make sure they eat their vegetables, don 't stay up too late, and don't watch too much TV. Otherwise just try to be as honest and open with them as possible. Roy eyes a picture of two little boys atop Klein's desk.
As honest and open as possible. (CONTINUED )
She's your daughter, Roy. Unless there's another ex-wife you haven't told me about, she's the only one you got.
Roy pulls home, pushing a pill from its packet, swallowing it dry, his second dose of the day. He gets out to find --
Angela lies by the pool on a beach towel in a bikini and dark glasses, reading a magazine.
How'd the meeting go? Did it go okay? Confronted by his daughter's breasts, hips and calves, Roy walks straight into the house.
What's the matter? You freaking out about something?

Squash, broccoli, artichokes, cauliflower, etc. Standing behind a cart, Roy stares at them blankly. In the frozen food aisle, Roy reads directions on a package of frozen spinach. Angela appears behind him, carrying chips, cookies, and a six-pack of beer.
Who's that for?
Don't you drink?
(shakes his head) Do you?
Come on. I'm fourteen. Roy isn't sure which way to take that.  85 86 87 88 89 90 50.

head_text.subj: IN LINE FOR ROY'S USUAL CHECK-OUT WOMAN 85

text: Roy and Angela wait behind two other shoppers.
The line for that one's shorter.
This one's better.

Roy cooks. His first attempt in years. He serves. Limp spinach and sauceless spaghetti. Seated at his breakfast table, neither he nor Angela look too ecstatic about digging in. He surrenders. A pizza delivery box takes center stage on the breakfast table; the spinach and pasta lie untouched in the kitchen sink. Angela bites into a slice as Roy forks a fresh can of tuna.
The morning ritual begins again. Roy, dressed, leaves his bedroom, closes its door behind him, proceeds to the bathroom door, opens it --
Just a minute. Roy closes it fast.
Roy cleans his coffee mug/wipes down the sink/waits. He's pissed his morning routine has been interrupted.
Angela exits, in a towel, allowing Roy to enter --

It looks like a circus act of seals has come and gone. Water everywhere, used towels, underpants hanging from a faucet. Roy uses a piece of toilet paper to remove them.  91 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 51.
Roy, bespectacled again, sits at a table with Frank and Frechette, who are halfway through lunch. Roy sticks with just coffee.
Bob tells me you're a yachtsman.
Hardly. Just a forty-two footer I take out on weekends. You sail?
I get seasick in the tub.
Arden, you sure you don't want something?
Thanks. I gotta fly in two hours. (To Frechette) The cast iron stomach again.
Where you off to?
Phoenix. A client's setting up a funding account to bridge the pound and the euro, I've got to hold his hand. (to passing waitress) Hon: could you heat this up a little, please?
That bad, huh?
For some folks, money is a foreign film without subtitles. Anyway, to the business at hand.
To the business at hand.
I have one rule, Chuck: simple is safe. I'm going to tell you as little as possible about me and what I do, but as much as I need to make you comfortable with what we're doing. (CONTINUED )
91 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 51a. CONTINUED: (Al) 91
What are we doing? Roy removes a manila envelope from his jacket, just as he did at Cheetah's, but reaches it under the table to Frechette. Frechette peeks inside: thin stacks of hundred pound notes.
How much is it? (CONTINUED )
Frechette 52. 91
Five thousand pounds sterling. One of the perks of working in the exchange program at a bank.
Whose is it?
No one's in particular. Justa little money unaccounted for, floating on top the books like a layer of cream.
And he just scoops it off.
It's a little more complicated than that but again: simple is safe.
Why not keep the money yourself?

As a bank employee any attempt I make to change currency is recorded and questioned. Bob has a record. You, on the other hand, no one bats an eye. (beat) Now I hope you have something for me. nods, removes an envelope from his jacket and reaches it under the table.
Five grand American. Roy checks, pockets Frechette's money.
Congratulations. At today's exchange rate, you just made two thousand --
-- five hundred sixty-seven dollars. I looked it up on the Internet. (CONTINUED )
The frickin' Internet. I still can't figure it out.
Neither can I. But my daughter's a wiz at the thing. Roy goes off-book.
You have a daughter?
Two. Fifteen and twelve.
I have a fourteen-year-old.
It's a riot, huh? Training bras hanging from your shower rod...
«+. and everything smells like gum. (suddenly has a thousand questions to ask Frechette) How do you get ‘em out of the house? Mine just sits at home all day.
Summer's the worst. Frank reacts: what the hell is Roy talking about?
At the valet station:
Lemme ask you something, Arden: how much could you do this for?
Hypothetically.
As a rule: we never go north of ten -- (CONTINUED )
Roy quiets Frank, eyes Chuck.
How much could you get your hands on? Frechette smiles.
Stiffing his valet, Frechette drives his Mercedes away. Frank and Roy watch him go. Frank sighs in relief.
For a second I thought we were out two grand.
You gotta spend money to make money.
But you gotta make it to spend it. (beat) ‘Everything smells like gum?' What was that about? Roy hesitates, then:
It's easier if I show you.
Roy unlocks the front door and enters, with Frank behind him. From within:
Angela! Angela, I'm back! (beat) Angela? Frank's here! (farther inside) Angela?
Frank reads a fashion magazine from Angela's bag. (CONTINUED )
She's not here. She must have gone back to her mom's.
Her bag's still here. Where does she usually go?
I don't know. I don't know anything about her.
This is no good for you, Roy. Or us.
It's got nothing to do with us.
Roy can be seen through the blinds, watching the pool, turning its light on and off.
An ashtray overflows on the coffee table. Roy waits on the couch and lights a fresh one. He checks his watch: it's late. A dull THUNK comes from the back of the house.
As Roy opens the door: Angela is brushing off her jeans. The window is open.
Where have you been?
Nowhere.
I've been waiting over an hour. Where did you go?
I went to the arcade. It's only like a half-mile away. (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 56.
He moves to the window, shuts it.
It's stuffy in here. This whole house smells like Lysol.
Where the hell were you? I want to know right now or I'm calling your mother.
I told you, the arcade --
Why'd you sneak back in?
That's how I left. I don't have keys to lock the door.
You didn't see my car? Roy squats to pluck up specks of dirt Angela tracked in.
Jeez, you're worse than Mom.

Listen, Angela: I'm glad we met, but I've got a business, a partner, and I've got things a certain way, and that's it. Sol think it would be better, for you most of all, if tomorrow morning I took you back home. Roy brushes the dirt into a trash can.
What did I do wrong?
You didn't do anything wrong.
I just went out. I didn't drink, I didn't get high, and I didn't take any money out of your stupid horse. (as Roy goes white) So, what, you never heard of a bank?  98 99 57.

Roy slides the head off his ceramic horse, checks his -38, then starts pulling out wads of cash. As he counts it, FOOTSTEPS march down the hall, punctuated by the front DOOR SLAMMING. Roy looks up. Should he go after her? He turns back to his money: it looks all there.
Angela stalks away from Roy's house, book bag and skateboard in hand. Roy emerges far behind her and runs to catch her. She, meanwhile, mounts her board.
Angela! I wasn't kicking you out.
I don't want to stay where I'm not wanted.
It's not that I don't want you.
Fooled me.
Will you stop? He catches her.
Let me go. (as he does) You just don't want me going home to Mom saying she was right all along. You're like one of her boyfriends: I'm just something you have to deal with in order to screw her.
Angela...
(much too loudly) Even they tell me what they do for a living. Oh, yeah, antique dealers always keep large stacks of cash in their homes. Right next to their guns... (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 58.
Roy shushes her, but he knows: she's got him.
Okay, okay. I'm sorry. I'm just... not good at being a father, alright? You know? I barely get by as me. Roy takes his hand out of his coat pocket to wipe a tear off her cheek. She recoils.
Will you come back home with me? We can get pizza again. She won't budge.
You can stay the whole weekend if you want. She won't budge. Roy doesn't know what else to offer but:
Why do you have a gun?
In case.
In case what? Roy is stuck. He sighs, resigned.
It's a little hard to explain.
Angela and Roy face off over another pizza.
Bullshit.
Nope. No bullshit. And watch your language at the table.
You're a con man? (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 58A.
Con artist. Flim-flam man, matchstick man, take your pick.
And that guy Frank?
My partner. My protege. (CONTINUED )
100 She considers it. A beat.
Bullshit.
I told you: watch your goddamn language.
Teach me something.
What?
Teach me something. A con.
You're funny.
Teach me something.
I am not going to teach you anything.
Why not?
Because. You're a beautiful, bright, innocent girl, and I'm not going to screw that up like everything else.
Really, you think that?
What?
That I'm beautiful?
(deadpan) No. (CONTINUED )
Then why won't you?! (mockingly) Because crime doesn't pay?
No. It does pay. Just not very well.
You seem to be doing okay by it. Roy stops.
I'm not. Believe me. It's not fun doing what I do. A lot of the time it's stealing from people who don't deserve it. Old people. Fat people. A lot of the time I feel sick about it.
(calling his bluff) Then why do you keep doing it? Roy has no answer.
As Roy brushes his teeth, Angela sits atop the toilet.
I'm not as innocent as you think. I've done stuff with boys. I've done stuff, if I told you, you'd probably throw up right here.
Then don't tell me.
Teach me something!
No! final!
At the Christmas dance last year, I went with this boy, Josh Ward, he's cute and I really really liked him... (CONTINUED )
I'm not listening.
After the dance, at Carrie's, we went upstairs, and he pushed me up against the bed...
I'm not listening.
And he took his hand...
One thing! I'11 show you one thing! She nearly jumps for joy. Kisses him on the cheek, getting toothpaste on her face, then skips down the hall.
And then you're never gonna do it again. You're gonna forget it. Agreed? But she's already frolicking into the living room.
Cruising down the freeway. Angela brings a notebook out of her backpack full of laundry.
Where we going?
Rule number one. Never work near where you live.
(writing) ‘Don't... shit... where... you...’
(grabs, throws notebook) Rule number two. Don't write anything down.  103 104
Roy exits the Caprice, enters the 7-Eleven. Angela follows.
Stay in the car. (as she still follows) Stay in the car. She still follows. Roy gives up.
103 104 Roy marks a lottery ticket as Angela watches: four of the five numbers -- 6, 18, 22, 49, 60 -- which (a prominent sign displays) won the day before. To the
I want to play this for the drawing on the twenty-second.
You know the odds of the lottery hitting the same numbers in the same month, the same numbers ever?
That's why I changed one.
You're wasting your dollar.
You his financial advisor?
No.
No. You're a cashier at a 7-Eleven. Take his dollar and give hima ticket for the twenty-second. The Cashier hops to it. Roy considers Angela, amused.
You sure you're ready for this?
I was born ready.
I'm glad I missed that day.  105 106 63.
Roy crumples up his lottery ticket, rolls it in his hand, scratches hard at it with his fingernail. Angela, sipping on a Big Gulp, takes it from him.
I've got longer nails. Roy watches her scratch away with all her might.

Just the... right. (beat) Okay. Most important thing you have to understand about this game is: ninety percent of it is variable. No matter how good your plan is, you almost always get thrown a curveball. So you have to be flexible, prepared to roll with anything. The one thing you can control, though, is who your mark is. That's your ten percent.
Angela enters, backpack on her arm. She cases the joint. A single man, black, sits reading Tolstoy.
Never play someone who's not buying what you're selling. What you're selling is you. An elderly couple separates whites and colors.
The older the better, but beware of couples. You don't want anyone whispering in your mark's ear but you. A boy in his teens returns her interest.

And, for God's sake, make sure the person you're conning isn't conning you. Angela gives him a get-lost look, then turns to a middle- aged HOUSEWIFE loading three machines. Angela approaches. (CONTINUED )
(re: washer beside her) That taken?
No.
Sure you don't need it? You've got a lot.
This is nothing. You oughta catch me during Little League season. Three boys.
Any of ‘em cute? The Housewife smiles, and Angela smiles back: she has her mark. She sets her bag down, stealthily planting the lottery ticket beneath it.
Angela and the Housewife transfer their laundry to dryers. Her dryer
Simon's about your age, but you'd never guess; he's so hyper. You know, girls really do mature much faster than boys.
That's what I keep telling my brothers.
They don't go to Fremont, do they?
Central. full, Angela picks up her backpack to go.
I'm gonna get a Coke across the street. Do you want anything? (CONTINUED )
No thanks, honey. Angela starts off, and the Housewife notices the lottery ticket left behind.
Honey, you dropped something. She holds it for her to see.
It's not mine.
You sure?
Gotta be eighteen to play.

Huh. Looks like someone put it through the wash by accident. It's for yesterday's drawing. That says the second, don't you think? Angela inspects it, too: thanks to her and Roy's handiwork, the date looks like the second, not the twenty-second.
Probably a loser. The Housewife nods, and Angela continues on her way. But on second thought:
We should at least see if it hit.
A man reads a newspaper. The Housewife approaches with Angela.
Excuse me, sir? Could we borrow your paper a sec? We're looking for lottery results. The newspaper drops. The man is Roy. (CONTINUED )
Sure. I think it's Metro... Roy hands her the section. The Housewife opens it, passes Angela the ticket. Roy rises to feed a dryer (whose clothes are inside is anybody's guess).
Ready? Six, eighteen, thirty, forty-nine, sixty.
Wait, wait. Six, eighteen, what?
Thirty, forty-nine, sixty.
Thirty? You're sure? (as Housewife nods) Missed by one.
You're joking.
Look!
You mean we missed by one number -- ? She looks -- it's true! They laugh, a little breathless, a little crestfallen. Then, it's back to the wash.
Story of my life.
Mine, too.
(as he returns) Any luck?
Four out of five, can you believe it?
Four out of five pays, you know. (CONTINUED )
Angela and the Housewife share a look, astonished.
It does?
Call the number on the ticket.
The Housewife's on a pay phone. Angela hovers nearby.
(into phone) Uh-huh, uh-huh. Thank you very much. She hangs up.
What'd they say?
(face erupting) We won six hundred dollars!
Holy -- She cups her mouth: oops.
-- shit! Six hundred dollars!
Holy shit! Roy watches from inside as they laugh and hug.
The woman on the phone said we just have to take it in for verification. And then they'll mail me a check. (quickly) I'll give you half, sweetie, don't worry.
You don't have to... (CONTINUED )
No, no, we're fifty-fifty in this. In fact, we should call your mom and we can all go down there together. Angela pulls back.
She works. Pretty late.
How ‘bout your dad?
(ashamed ) He -- he doesn't live with us anymore. You know, it's okay. I'm supposed to be home anyway.
No, no, no. We're in this fifty- fifty. The Housewife stops to think -- what to do? Then she turns to see a bank ATM across the street.
The Housewife uses the ATM; Angela's feet are barely IN FRAME behind her. Angela very consciously keeps OUT OF the CAMERA'S RANGE.
Roy watches from inside his Caprice.
Good girl, watch the cameras.
The Housewife hands Angela three crisp $100s.
That’s three hundred. Don't spend it all at the coin-op. And hide it when you get home. Don't let those brothers of yours anywhere near it. (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 69.
(touched) Thank you.
Thank you, sweetie. They hug again.
Angela exits with her backpack full of laundry, waves goodbye once more to the Housewife, then rounds a corner to find Roy waiting for her, out of sight.
Did I do good?
You did very good. She leaps in the air.
Mom was wrong: I didn't just get your elbows.
One last thing...
Uh-huh?
Go give her her money back.
What?!
I told you I'd teach you acon, I didn't say I'd let you get away with it.
C'mon! You're joking.
(shakes his head) Now. (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 70.
(can't believe it) This is so... Roy points: go. Petulantly, Angela stalks back inside. Roy watches through a glass wall as she hands the money back to the Housewife, utterly befuddled.
Driving Angela home.

I have one question for you. And I want you to think before answering. (as she nods okay) Did you feel better when you took her money, or when you gave it back? (before she answers) Think first. Angela thinks.
I thought we were partners.
I'm not your partner. I'm your father. Angela puts her feet up on the dash. Roy doesn't mind.
It's strange. Two weeks ago this was ancient history. Now suddenly I have a daughter.
And I'm not... scared shitless. That's good, isn't it?
It's however you feel about it, Roy. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 71.
DR. KLEIN (CONT'Dbeat) Yes. It's wonderful. Don't take this too literally, but you've been closing doors for a long time. It's good to see you start opening some again. Roy looks a little worried.
What?

I -- I took Angela along over the weekend, selling a piece. Sometimes in my business you have to create a value in something which really isn't there. What some people call sales, other people call...
Lying.
I didn't know how Angela would go for that. But she took right to it. She even helped out, this fourteen-year-old girl, working these people with me.
Do you regret it? Exposing her to that? Her seeing that side of you?
(moment of truth) I really liked it. It was the best time we've had together.

Roy opens his refrigerator door. Inside are grease- stained pizza cartons and Chinese food cartons. He closes it, considers the room around him. It's cluttered with fashion magazines, empty soda cans, a real mess. And it's very quiet, for the first time in a while. And lonely.  116 117 118 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 72.
Cans of tuna again. But also some fresh vegetables, frozen pizzas, and TV dinners.
Where's that cute little girl of yours?
She went home to her mom's. Summer school.
She's a cute one. Must be lonesome without her. Roy considers her as she bags his groceries.
I'll see you tomorrow. (hesitates, then) It's Kathy, right? (off her nod) I'm Roy.
Hi, Roy. They shake. Two people meeting after seeing each other every day for months.
Roy walks through the terminal.

Before noon, the place is mostly deserted. One or two layovers at the bar and a custodian vacuuming the floors. Roy and Frank case the place. Roy, a standard-sized black briefcase beside him, withdraws a cigarette; Frank bums one from him.
He said he wants to fly the money straight to the Caymans. Afraid he might get robbed.
As if someone would do that. When's his flight? (CONTINUED )
118 119 120 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 72a.
Friday. (beat) Where do you think? Roy points at...
Roy sits facing the bar, against a wall, the standard- sized black briefcase beside him.
You plant this before the meet. And keep the table free. I'm here, you sit him there, back to the bar. Otherwise we blow it off.
Who's the drunk gonna be?
Ernie.
Typecasting.
What do you expect for fifty bucks? Frank scans the place once more, a little nervous.
There's only one problem. (as Roy waits: what?) I think I'm in love with you. Frank lets out a whoop! He's going to be rich.
Roy stands alone in the middle of the lounge, looking from table to bar, then to all the walls. Running the plan over in his head.
Summer school lets out. Roy scours the young teens flooding from the school from his Caprice across the street. (CONTINUED )
120 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 72B. CONTINUED: (Al) 120
Perv. She's snuck up behind him. He smiles.
In the car. She gets in, looks at him, grins.
What would you like to do today, little girl?
Mom says I have to be back by dinner. (CONTINUED )
You'll be back by dinner. What would you like to do? She grins even wider. Roy blanches dramatically: Uh-oh.

Uh-oh was right. Angela lifts a bowling ball up to her eyes, then lets it rip down an alley -- CRASH! Meanwhile, Roy cleans his ball meticulously with his handkerchief -- even the finger holes. It's his turn to bowl now and, with a swallow for courage, he plunges his fingers into the ball to pick it up. Angela passes him on the way back to her seat.
I own you. Roy glares at her, then steps up to the alley. Concentrates. Approaches and releases his first roll. Gutter ball. Keeping his chin high, he retreats to the ball return.

(approaching him gently) Dad. The first thing you have to understand about this game is: ninety-percent of it is knocking down at least one pin. He grabs at her, and she screams with laughter. And just then -- BEEP BEEP BEEP -- it's Roy's PAGER going off. He checks it, sighs.
You want me to bowl for you?
Roy thinks about wiping the receiver down, but his handkerchief has already gone dirtier places. Over the MUSIC and CRASHING PINS, he yells: (CONTINUED )
122 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 74.
It's me, what is it? (beat) What?! I thought it wasn't ‘til Friday! (beat) Well, tell him -- Roy's face falls. Angela, bowling in the distance, rolls a strike and leaps in the air.
Frank's on a cellular headset, rubbing his temples, stressed.
I know, I know, he bumped it up. He says he won't be back for a month. (beat) I don't want to lose him, Roy.
Now Roy's stressed, too.
There's no time. I gotta get the money, change, get Ernie... What time's his flight? Roy's face falls. Angela, bowling in the distance, rolls a strike and leaps in the air.
Roy exits, in a rush, and Angela trudges out behind, pissed.
I'm sorry. It just came up. I gotta take you home.
(it's not) It's okay. (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 75.
I can't, uh, I just can't -- (looks at watch) I can't do this. There's no time. I can't even take you home.
(playing the victim) You want me to take the bus?
No. shit! He doesn't know what to do.
Is it a job? Roy nods.
(timidly) Can I help? Roy considers her, thinks, then:
Yes.
(excitedly) Really? Roy nods, unhappily.
What do I get to do? Roy thinks. Is this the worst idea he's ever had?
Shit!
Roy, with standard-sized black briefcase, enters with Angela.
I thought you kept all your money in the horse. (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 76.
That's just my piggy bank. Wait here. He heads downstairs. She follows, as usual.
Roy and Angela approach the Clerk.
I'd like access to my safe deposit box. J-215.
(offering form) Signature and pass code, please. Roy starts to fill it out. Covers the pass code from Angela's prying eyes. In whispers:
Why can't I see?
‘Cause it's a secret.
Then why does he get to? Roy thinks. To the Clerk:
Can I add an access signature to my account. The Clerk nods, puts forth another form. Roy pushes it toward Angela.
Sign here and here.
Do it. She does. Back to whispers:
So, what, now I can get into the whatever-it-is?
No. You don't have the pass code. (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 76A.
When do I get that?
When I'm dead.
(forlorn) Oh.
Don't weep for me too much. Now wait here. I mean it.

Roy opens his deposit box. Inside are bound, neat stacks of hundred dollar bills and hundred-pound notes, piled atop a fist-high ream of bonds. He starts picking up stacks of cash and placing them in the black briefcase. He closes the case, feels its weight. Then, to the guard around the corner:
Hey: you got today's Times?
Roy exits with Angela.
How much is in there?
(re: briefcase) I told you.
(re: bank) No, in there. Three hundred thousand? He just smiles: not telling.
Five hundred thousand? A million? He shrugs. Angela is flabbergasted.
How did you --
I've been doing this a long time.
Why aren't you -- why don't you go live in Hawaii? Why don't you buy Hawaii?
I told you: I don't like the outdoors.
Roy puts on his Arden glasses.
These still make me look old?
Old and rich. Roy checks his watch. He's really not certain about this. 77. 126 127 (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 78.

You know what to do? (off her nod) You keep real far away from us. Anything seems off, you get outta there. You see me tug my tie like this, you get outta there. He gives her two hundreds from his wallet.
Take this. Just in case.
Stop worrying about me. I'm barely even doing anything. He gives the whole plan one more thought. Shakes his head. She looks at him with puppy eyes.
What?
Please, can I have the pass code? He has to laugh.

Roy enters, carrying the black briefcase, and immediately he spots a problem: Frank sits in the banquette seat Roy should have. Roy continues his approach, clasping his back now and wincing. Frank and Frechette greet him.
Arden, you okay?
My back. Strained it last night.
I told you: You should do yoga.
(a joke) I was doing yoga. You mind if I sit there. The high back helps. (CONTINUED )
128 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 79.
Frank and Roy change seats, Roy sneaking a reproachful glance Frank's way: nice fucking job. As he sits, with difficulty:
How are both of you? Across the lounge, Angela peeks out from behind a partition to watch Roy, Frank and Chuck. A waitress delivers Roy a club soda and departs.
So: who goes first? Roy and Frechette face off: who will make the first move?

I suppose ladies do. The Queen before Ben Franklin. Roy lifts his black briefcase onto an empty chair between them and cracks it open just enough for Frechette to see: a newspaper. Frechette pries underneath: wall-to-wall British pounds inside.
That's eighty thousand? It looks like less than I thought.
It always does. Frechette reaches in to flip through a stack of bills: they're all real.
Sorry. Had to check.

As long as you don't mind. Roy closes the case and sets it down on the floor by his feet. Meanwhile, Frechette replaces it with a gym bag. As he unzips it, Roy steals a glance at the lounge entrance: Angela is entering.
Go ahead. Do your worst. (CONTINUED )
128 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 80.
Roy explores the gym bag: it's loaded with stacks of hundred dollar bills.
(to Frank) You count it? Frank nods. A pregnant pause. Then:
It looks like we have a trade.
God bless America.
Land that I love. Roy salutes him with his soda, and Frank and Frechette raise their Scotches to toast --
Enjoy the Caymans. Don't get too much sun.
You kidding? He's going there for the shelter. Suddenly, from the bar:
Oh, come on! I'm twenty-one! Roy peers up and Frank and Frechette turn to look: Angela is screaming at the lounge bartender.
My I.D. is in my luggage! My plane doesn't leave for thirty minutes! Can't I get a goddamn beer?! The bartender cautions her and she grabs a tumbler --

You touch me, I'll break every glass in this place. -- then hurls the GLASS down at the floor, SHATTERING it, drawing every eye, including Frechette's, and that's when Roy pulls the switch: the briefcase stowed beneath the banquette for the identical one by his feet. Lightning fast. (CONTINUED )
128 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 81.

Hey, you! Airport bartender! Angela backs out of the lounge, arms raised, giving the finger with both hands to the bartender. And she's gone. Frechette turns back, none the wiser. Frank knows, of course -- Angela's tantrum was part of the act -- and he looks at Roy incredulously.
Hope she isn't on my flight. Speaking of which: it's about that time. Who goes first?
You do. Just get up and take your new briefcase with you. When I leave, I'll take my new gym bag.
Simple is safe. Roy nods to his wisdom, then pushes the briefcase at his feet across to Frechette. Frechette picks it up, bids Frank and Roy farewell --
Guys. Let's do it again some time.
Have a safe flight. -- and departs. Roy and Frank watch him go.
(under his breath) What the hell was that?
Go with him.
That wasn't --
Walk him to the plane.
They won't let me past the security check. (CONTINUED )
130 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 82.

Then walk him to the security check. Frank follows Roy's orders and chases after Frechette. Roy reaches under the banquette and grabs the briefcase there. A bag in one hand, the case in the other, he takes off in the opposite direction.
Roy exits briskly, crossing to the parking garage.
Roy emerges from a stairwell and Angela leaps from behind a pillar to surprise him.
Boo! Roy keeps walking, despite a minor cardiac, all business as Angela bounces around him.
Did you see that old chick at the bar? With all the makeup? She almost died when I threw that glass.
I saw her.
What happened on our end? You take him? He nods.
The whole eighty? Roy nods. Angela bounces higher, singing:
‘My dad's a smooth operator! Smooth operator!’
As Roy pulls out of his spot: (CONTINUED )
130 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 83.
Dad, I thought about it: we should give the money back. I'd feel better. He looks at her, and she smiles: just joking. He's not in the mood.
Do I get a cut?

You can ask Frank for his. Roy stops behind a minivan pulling out of a spot, and he turns to see: -- the stairwell door fly open and Frechette appear, ina fury, suitcase open and empty, looking this way and that. He spots Roy instantly and starts toward him. Roy punches the gas, around the minivan and away.

(oblivious to Frechette) Dad?! Roy races down levels of parking lot as Frechette chases on foot. With a fair lead, the Caprice comes to four gated exit lanes, two cars in the three of them, one car in the fourth. Roy chooses that one.
(frightened now) Dad?

Roll up your window! Now! Get down on the floor! Angela does as she's told. His money ready, Roy waits for the car ahead of him to pass through, but the ATTENDANT seems to be taking forever to make change. Meanwhile, the other lanes are clearing up quickly. Roy considers backing up and choosing another exit, but the minivan he passed now hovers behind him. He's trapped. And Frechette appears in his sideview mirror, hustling toward him. At last, Roy pulls up to the parking Attendant, thrusts his money at her, then barks:
Open the gate, please. (CONTINUED )
130 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 83A.
Do you need a receipt --
No! Please open the gate. The gate comes up, but too late. Frechette is upon them, on Angela's side, yanking on the door, rabid.
Dad! Roy hits the gas, and the Caprice slaps the gate as it rises, but before they're clear, Frechette gets a clean look at Angela hovering below the seat.
(slamming steering wheel) Dammit!
Are we okay? Roy looks down to her, balled up, shaking with fear. He has no one to blame for this but himself.  131 132 133 84.

The Dodgers are away, leaving acres of parking spots unused. Los Angeles looms in the distance. Frank paces beside his car and chain smokes as Roy's Caprice pulls up. Frank steps up to see Roy glowering at him.
What? No reply. Roy just seethes.
Hiya, Frank.
(at a loss) Hiya. (back to glowering Roy) What?!
(to Angela) Stay in the car.
But I want to --
Stay in the car! Roy gets out, slams the door, then reopens it, turns the RADIO ON to an EARSPLITTING VOLUME, slams the door again.
Angela can't hear anything but MUSIC as Roy tears Frank a new one.
I said 'walk him to the plane.' Did you walk him to the plane?
I told you: security. They don't let you to the gate without a ticket -- (CONTINUED )
Did you see him go through security?
Yes!
Did you wait 'til the plane left the gate?
You told me to walk him there, I walked him there.
Frank, my daughter was there today! Frank looks away, chastened. Says something half under his breath.
What?
I'm not the one who pimped her into the grift. And don't tell me I'm the one who put her at risk. She put us at risk.
How?
What if he goes to the cops?
He won't. They never do.
What if he does?
Then he'd have to explain what he was doing with eighty grand and a ticket to the Caymans. (beat) We're not on the books. We're safe. (CONTINUED )
I know we are. What about her?
Angela's never been arrested --
You don't know that. You don't know that! What if Chuck goes to the cops? Roy turns: Angela watches from inside the car. He opens the door.
Turn it off. She does. Frank leers at Roy: ask her.
Tell him, Angela, and let's get this over with. Tell him you're clean. (beat) You've never been arrested, have you? Angela looks from Roy to Frank to Roy again. Then blushes. And bites her lip.
Terrific.
Roy hands Frank Frechette's bag of money, and Frank starts toward his car, and the younger man takes off. Roy leans against his hood as Angela remains in her seat.
I would have told you, but it never came up. Roy gives her the silent treatment a moment, then:
You're fourteen! When did you have time to get arrested?
I forgot to pay for a pack of gum once, that's it. (CONTINUED )
(disbelief) They called the cops on you for a pack of gum.
And some other stuff. I mighta put up a fuss when security --
Angela...
The guard was groping me. He was grabbing at my chest, what was I supposed to do?
How long ago?
Last year.
And they photographed you? They printed you? Angela nods and bows her head penitently. Roy, his hands slowly returning to his coat pockets, takes a stroll, super-pissed.
Roy drives, brow knit, thinking. Angela sneaks a glance at him, knows enough not to speak.
Roy's Caprice pulls to a stop, Heather's house in the distance.
Roy looks straight ahead, arctic. Angela tries to thaw him. (CONTINUED )
You know, I have all of August off. I was thinking maybe I could come stay with you. He says nothing.
Or we could take a trip even. Oh, and in September is father's visiting day at school. It's kind of lame, but I thought maybe... Silence. Then:
I'm gonna be gone for the next couple months. Frank and I have some out-of-town work. She nods, hurt but trying to conceal it. Tears form regardless.
When do you think you'll be back?
I don't know.
Maybe when you get back --

(killing hope) You're getting in the way. Okay? I thought maybe it could work out, but it can't. Frank and I are partners. He wants you gone, you're gone. Angela's lip trembles and tears faucet down her cheeks.
Is it, did I -- Roy keeps staring straight ahead. Angela cries, elbows in her hands, arms clutching her gut.
I'm sorry... I didn’t mean to... Roy, tortured, can't look at her. (CONTINUED )
138 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 89.

Can we at least talk on the phone? Roy says nothing. She weeps openly. Roy shrinks as he sees a woman dragging trash barrels to the curb. Mid- thirties, a faded beauty. HEATHER. He watches with curiosity.

You wanna know why your mom left me? She left me because of you. So you wouldn't grow up with me as your dad. (beat) I am a bad guy. Roy can't stand this anymore. He leans over her and opens the passenger door.
C'mon. Your mom'll be waiting. Angela wipes tears away. Anger supplanting grief. She digs into her backpack, withdraws an object wrapped in an "LA AIRPORT GIFT SHOP" bag, sets it on the dash.
What's that?
I got it for you at the airport. (beat) I paid for it. She starts out of the car, but Roy doesn't want to let her go angry.
Ange -- She spins on him, furious, tears streaming.
Why did you even call me?! Why did you? Roy has no answer.
You're not a bad guy, you know. You're just not a very good one. (CONTINUED )
138 MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 B9A.
She slams the door behind her. The interior light fades on Roy. He unwraps the gift shop bag: It's an "I Love LA" ashtray. FADE OUT.  139 140 141 90.

Dark. Roy's on the couch, arm thrown over his eyes. Hair unkempt, unshaven, wearing clothes for the third day in a row, the room around him a pigsty. Roy has let the place and himself go. The PHONE RINGS. And RINGS. And RINGS. At last, Roy picks it up.
Hello.
Roy? You alright?
Yeah.
You hungry? He discards an empty can of tuna from the couch.
No.
You wanna meet? We still got Chuck's money to split.
What time is it?
Almost three.
Hold on a sec. He hangs up. Doesn't move.
Also a mess. Roy rinses out a dirty coffee cup. Fills it with water. Watches it overflow. Reaches up to a cupboard for his pills. They're not there. Roy furrows his brow.
Roy looks inside his bedside table. Looks around it. They're not here either.  142 143 91.
He scours his medicine cabinet, then inspects the waste basket, looks beneath the sink. The only thing here is one of Angela's barrettes.
He pushes and backtracks through rooms, checking coat pockets in wardrobes, looking everywhere for his pills as he speaks on his portable phone:
Medical group.
Doctor Klein, please.
I'm sorry, Dr. Klein is unavailable. Dr. Wiley is on call, if you'd like to --
I gotta talk to Klein. Is there a way of getting hold of him?
Dr. Klein has gone for the weekend.
Where'd he go? Look, look: I need a new thing of pills. Are you there at the office now? Roy's PHONE BEEPS. He checks it.
Shit, my phone's dying.
Sir, if this is an emergency, I recommend you contact a local hospital --
Listen: can you let me in his office -- (CONTINUED )
-- sir, I can't --
-- I know where he keeps them, or gimme Klein's home phone --
-- Dr. Wiley is on call --
-- I need to talk to Klein -- The phone dies --
Shit! -- and he hurls it against a wall.
Roy goes through the trash beneath his sink.
Roy at rock-bottom. He digs though his trash bin, then upends it. Cans and cans of Chicken-of-the-Sea rattle on the pavement. But no pills.
Roy presses his cheek against the floor mat of his car. He peers beneath the driver's seat, then reaches in and pats the floor, recovering -- -- one empty foil packet.
The Caprice swerves into traffic. Nearly forces several cars off the road. Surges ahead.  148 93.
Located in the rear of a discount drugstore. Five people stand on line for the white-coated, white-haired PHARMACIST. Roy joins the back of the line, wild-eyed, wild-haired, impatient.
C'mon, c'mon. A few customers look back at Roy. He stares their glances away. Soon he can wait no longer. He pushes to the front of the line, empty packet in hand.
Hi, I need a refill of this. I don't have a prescription, but --
Sir, please, wait your turn --
I know, but this is an emergency !--
Hey, buddy: ever hear of a line?
(turning) Ever been dragged onto the sidewalk and beaten till you piss blood? That decides it: nobody's screwing with Roy. The Pharmacist scans the horizon for security, doesn’t see anyone.
Please. I need a refill.
Do you have a prescription?
My shrink, my doctor, he gave me these. They're samples of -- I can't remember -- Prefex- something.
I'm sorry. Without a prescription!-- (CONTINUED )
Look: I have the packet --
I can't help you, sir.
-- So I'm clearly allowed to have them. I just need four or five of these to cover the weekend.
(resigning) Let me see it. The Pharmacist takes the empty packet from Roy. Studies it. Hands it back.
Those are vitamins.
What?
That packet contained vitamins.
No. My doctor gave it to me. Prefex...
They're vitamins, sir. Supplifen. Aisle four. Roy stands there, incredulous, infuriated. In aisle four, he rips open a box of Supplifen to find the replica of the packet he was given. He crushes it.
Klein exits his sedan. Fumbling for his office key, he approaches the front door when Roy appears in the breezeway behind him, shoulders heaving, threatening. Klein gasps, startled, then:
Roy? I'm not supposed to see you ‘till -- (CONTINUED )
Vitamins. You gave me goddamn vitamins. Klein appraises Roy: he is not to be trifled with right now.
Klein enters with Roy, turns on a light.
Would you like to sit?
I am sitting. A beat.
Roy: why do you think you need medication?
You are not asking questions yet. First you answer: did you give me vitamins?
Yes.
Why?
Because you don’t need medication.
Look at me. I'm a mess.

Agreed. But you weren't a mess last week, and you weren't on Prefexall then either. (beat) I have news for you, Roy. Your neurosis is small-time. Your conscience is another story. (before Roy retorts) Let me ask a question. Does what you do make you happy? (CONTINUED )
A beat. 96. 150
Don't change the subject.
This is the subject. What would you do if you had to change careers?
If I couldn't be an antiques broker?
If you couldn't be a criminal. (beat) This is a 17th Century Williamsburg ottoman I've had my feet on for the last two months, Roy. I've had computer programmers tell me what a nice piece it is.
I'm not a criminal. I'ma con man.
The difference being?
They give me their money.
That's a nice rationalization, Roy.
I never took anybody who didn't let me out of greed or weakness. I've never used violence.
Would you say then you set an example in your trade?
Sure. (CONTINUED )
MATCHSTICK MEN - Rev. 7/17/02 97.
But now you have to set an example for someone else. (beat) How is she?
(beat) Angela? Fine. (as Klein waits him out) She wants back to her mom's.
Have you spoken to her? (as Roy shakes his head) Why not?
Do we have to talk about this?
Why haven't you spoken?
(a beat) Because she hates me.
Why do you think she hates you? Roy's face crumbles, and everything pours out:
Because I -- because I -- Oh, Christ, Doc! I lost my little girl! I lost my little girl!
Frank considers what Roy has told him. (CONTINUED )
When?
As of now. Roy waits for Frank's reaction: is he pissed?
(he's not) You gotta do what you gotta do. I'm sorry to lose you. (beat) You want your forty g's?
Consider it a parting gift.
We should part more often.
Thanks, Frank. For everything.
Thank you, partner. They shake hands. Frank gestures to the door.
The place is clean again. Roy opens a Radio Shack box, pulls out a new portable phone. Reads its instructions.
Roy sits on his bed, phone in hand. Gathering his nerve. He twirls between his fingers the barrette he found in his bathroom. At last, he dials. One ring, two rings.
Roy sits waiting. Looks up as Angela approaches on her skateboard. Roy smiles. Angela does not.
They walk along a path. (CONTINUED )

I went to see a lawyer. He specializes in custody suits, that sort of thing. Like when one parent wants to get joint custody of the child. (off no reaction from her) There are things you have to do. File paperwork, blood tests, go before a judge. It would only be for weekends and some holidays to start. Still no reaction.

I'd have to make some changes. For one, I'm gonna have to stop doing what I do for a living. (as Angela stops, turns away) Honey, I'm sorry. I should have asked you first. She looks up at him, tears in her eyes, and throws her arms around him.
Will you try? Please?
(soaring) Yes. I'll try, honey. I'1l try. He wraps his arms around her and holds her.
Roy and Angela celebrate, Angela in a new-bought dress, which makes her fidget. A JAZZ COMBO PLAYS in the next room.
You know, I should talk to your mom about this. Let her know what I'm doing.
Your funeral. (CONTINUED )
I know. But she should hear it from me.
We could get a dog. Either a German shepherd or a Lab.
(uneasily) They're messy, aren't they?
Not if you train 'em. We can name it Frank.
That's a good name. They both smile. A WAITER pours Angela more Diet Coke.
Mademoiselle... Angela suppresses a laugh.

head_text.subj: ON DANCE FLOOR IN NEXT ROOM

text: A few couples dance. Angela leads a reluctant Roy to the floor. She holds up her arms for him to take, and he balks.
Please... He gives in. Takes her hands in his and, very tentatively, begins to box-step. Concentrates mostly on his feet, then remembers to concentrate on Angela. And she, throughout, just beams.
Dark. They enter, laughing. Angela is imitating the French Waiter as Roy fumbles the key out of the lock.
Mademoiselle... Bonjour, mademoiselle. O-reev-ar, mademoiselle... (CONTINUED )
Au revoir.
What?
Au revoir. Au... Roy switches on a lamp, then leaps back: Chuck Frechette is sitting on his sofa. Cigarette in hand, handgun resting on the cushion beside him. Big smirk.
Hello, Roy. Hiya, sunshine. Roy freezes/considers the variables: the open door behind him, Angela before him.
Close the door. (as Roy hesitates) Close it. Roy considers Frechette's gun, does as he says. Angela trembles halfway between them.
Dad?
Go wait in your room, honey.
